auxiliary_meanings.meaning: First Time In A Long Time
For The First Time In A Long Time
For The First Time In Many Years
For The First Time In Ages
It's Been For A Long Time

meaning_mnemonic: This is kind of a "set phrase" in Japanese, though we're going to treat it like a vocab word here (because it's so common and useful!). You know that <kanji>久</kanji> means "long time" - so now let's pay attention to the kana: しぶり. Just imagine that <reading>she buri</reading>ed you alive, then a few days later came back to dig you up. The first thing she says is "<vocabulary>LONG TIME NO SEE!</vocabulary>"

真似 is "impersonation." Actually, this word is too. It's also <vocabulary>impersonation</vocabulary>.

物真似 is very similar to 真似, but can be used in slightly different contexts. 真似 is used for general acts of mimicry or imitation, and can also be used to refer to the way someone does something. On the other hand, while 物真似 also describes acts of mimicry and imitation, it's additionally used in performance or entertainment contexts to refer to people who do impersonation acts.

If 複数 is <kanji>multiple</kanji>, and 形 is <kanji>shape</kanji>, then when something is in a "multiple shape," it has more than one version of itself. It's the <vocabulary>plural</vocabulary>, or the <vocabulary>plural form</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>heart</kanji> <kanji>internal organs</kanji> is the <vocabulary>heart</vocabulary>, of course.
The <kanji>lung</kanji> <kanji>internal organ</kanji> is the <vocabulary>lung</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Inside</kanji> <kanji>internal organs</kanji> are your <vocabulary>internal organs</vocabulary>, though you'd think the second kanji would give a hint to that without the 内.

越す is "to go beyond." Now you're going beyond your home and <kanji>pull</kanji>ing everything with you to go to another home. You are trying <vocabulary>to move</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>to move homes</vocabulary>.

越す means "to go beyond." 追 is <kanji>follow</kanji>. If you are following someone, and then you go beyond them, you have overtaken them. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to overtake</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to surpass</vocabulary>.

You know that 祖父 is grandfather and 祖母 is grandmother. This is both combined. Is it some hybrid grandmapa monster you've created in your lab? Hardly, it just refers to your <vocabulary>grandparents</vocabulary>.
You know that to 飼う is "to keep a pet." If you're the <kanji>master</kanji> that is <kanji>keeping a pet</kanji> (飼う), then you are the <vocabulary>pet owner</vocabulary>.

You つける (attach) a <kanji>wound</kanji> to someone or something. In other words, this means <vocabulary>to hurt someone</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to scratch</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to damage</vocabulary> something.
After you <kanji>use</kanji> it you <kanji>throw away</kanji> it, making whatever it is you used a <vocabulary>disposable</vocabulary> item.
You <kanji>throw</kanji> and <kanji>throw away</kanji> something. That's why this means <vocabulary>to throw away</vocabulary>.

You know the kanji 込 means <kanji>into</kanji>. This verb is transitive, meaning you are doing the action. If you “do something into something” you are putting it into that thing. So this means <vocabulary>to put in</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to load something</vocabulary>.

I must <kanji>say humbly</kanji> that I want to get <kanji>into</kanji> this position, so I'm planning <vocabulary>to apply</vocabulary> for it and <vocabulary>to submit an application</vocabulary>.

申し込む isn't just about applying, though. It's about officially communicating desires, whether you want <vocabulary>to propose</vocabulary> marriage, challenge someone to a game of tennis, or even offer a donation to a good cause.

To <kanji>fly</kanji> <kanji>into</kanji> something and "commit suicide" (自殺) is <vocabulary>suicide by train</vocabulary>. Unfortunately, this is a term you should probably be familiar with because it comes up from time to time on the news and around train stations. (Hopefully someday it will no longer be a term you need to know and we can remove it forever.)

You know that 書く is "to write" and the kanji 込 is into, so this means <vocabulary>to write in</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to fill out</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to jot down</vocabulary>.

書き込む focuses more on the physical action of writing than 書く on its own. This is because 込む stresses that you’re putting words INTO some space, either on paper or on computer.

When a <kanji>person</kanji> goes <kanji>into</kanji> a place (then another person goes into the place, and then another person and another person), that place eventually gets filled with a <vocabulary>crowd of people</vocabulary>.

Note that this word is more commonly written 人混み.
This is the noun version of 染. A dye would seem like the right answer, but what else is a dye? If you get it on you when you don't want to get it on you, it becomes a <vocabulary>stain</vocabulary>.

If 染める is "to dye," then this is <vocabulary>to be dyed</vocabulary>. You aren't doing the dyeing, because you know that if you did it you would have done things right, unlike the other person who dyed your hair. This person <reading>marr</reading>ed (まる) it up really bad.

汚れる is "to get dirty." This is when you make something dirty, aka "<vocabulary>to make dirty</vocabulary>." You know that this is the version where you make things dirty yourself because when you make someone dirty with all that poop you're flinging, they <reading>sue</reading> (す) you immediately. This happens a lot.
You <kanji>say</kanji> a <kanji>reason</kanji> for your actions, but really it's just an <vocabulary>excuse</vocabulary>.

You know that 詰める is "to stuff in" and the kanji 込 is <kanji>into</kanji>. When you’re stuffing something into something else, you are going <vocabulary>to stuff</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to cram</vocabulary> it in.

Just as in English, this word can also be used in a figurative sense, like cramming knowledge into your head.

It's my <kanji>delight</kanji> to <kanji>welcome</kanji> you, so I give you a big, warm <vocabulary>welcome</vocabulary>.

歓迎 is a relatively formal word that refers to warmly accepting someone in, like <vocabulary>welcoming</vocabulary> someone who's arrived somewhere or joined a group.
Your <kanji>blood</kanji> <kanji>fluid</kanji> <kanji>type</kanji> is your <vocabulary>blood type</vocabulary>. This is a very important thing to know in Japan for some reason.
興味 is <kanji>interest</kanji> in something. If you do not have (がない) that interest, then you have <vocabulary>no interest</vocabulary> or you're <vocabulary>not interested</vocabulary>.

The 賛成 portion means "agreement", "approval", or "support", so the verb version would also be <vocabulary>to agree</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to approve</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to support</vocabulary>!
A <kanji>mistake</kanji> in what you <kanji>solve</kanji>... wow, sorry, I thought I was supposed to solve this, not that. What a terrible <vocabulary>misunderstanding</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>mistake</kanji> in <kanji>letter</kanji>s is a <vocabulary>typo</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>mistake</kanji> in <kanji>use</kanji> is a <vocabulary>misuse</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>mistake</kanji> in what you <kanji>calculate</kanji> is a <vocabulary>miscalculation</vocabulary>.

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. This adjective describes things that are <kanji>valuable</kanji> in a way that transcends monetary worth, so it means <vocabulary>noble</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>invaluable</vocabulary>.

While 尊い is used for things you honor from the heart, 貴い leans toward a dignified, noble kind of value — the kind tied to high status or social rank. Because of that, you may encounter 貴い in stories about historical class systems or old social hierarchies. It doesn't appear as commonly as 尊い in modern Japanese, but you may still see it in descriptions of someone's noble presence or the sense of dignity they give off.

The <kanji>older brother</kanji> is <kanji>valuable</kanji> to you. But, no matter how valuable he is to you, he's still just your <vocabulary>older brother</vocabulary>. 

P.S. You'll often see some gangstah thug call a higher ranking gangstah thug (one that acts like an older brother to all the other gangstah thugs) this. It's like family within the gang.

A <kanji>valuable</kanji> <kanji>formal name ender</kanji>. It's like saying "the valuable great you"... or something. Anyways, this means <vocabulary>you</vocabulary>, but it isn't as nice as it sounds.

貴様 used to be a polite way to say "you," but in modern Japanese it's almost always a strong insult, roughly like saying <vocabulary>you bastard</vocabulary>. The tone is dramatic, so you'll hear it from anime villains, but not usually in real conversation unless someone's joking around and pretending to be Vegeta from Dragon Ball.

People of a <kanji>valuable</kanji> <kanji>tribe</kanji> are part of <vocabulary>the nobility</vocabulary>. Unlike our tribes, they are valuable.

貴族 refers to a noble or <vocabulary>aristocrat</vocabulary> in old social systems, so you mostly see it in history books or fantasy settings. In modern Japanese, people sometimes use it jokingly when a person does something very luxurious or indulgent — as if they're living like an aristocrat for a moment.
I am going to <kanji>descend</kanji> my <kanji>participat</kanji>ion in this conflict. I am going to descend all my weapons to the ground. I am going to <vocabulary>surrender</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>cow</kanji> <kanji>rice bowl</kanji> is a bowl of rice covered in beef, making it a <vocabulary>beef bowl</vocabulary>. Go get some Yoshinoya.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

To be exact, 丼 refers to a chinaware bowl that's bigger and sturdier than your ordinary <vocabulary>rice bowl</vocabulary>. It's often used for one-bowl dishes like katsudon, gyūdon, poke, but also noodle soups like ramen!

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>throw up</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to throw up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to puke</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to spit</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Some <kanji>dude</kanji> who is a <kanji>slave</kanji> is just a <vocabulary>slave</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>shrink</kanji> so the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to shrink</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Shrink</kanji> what you have into something <kanji>small</kanji>. It was big, now it's small. This is a <vocabulary>reduction</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Simple</kanji> and <kanji>pure</kanji>. This is <vocabulary>simple</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Not</kanji> <kanji>pure</kanji> things are <vocabulary>impure</vocabulary>.
Something that is <kanji>pure</kanji> <kanji>fur</kanji> is pure fur... but what kind of fur? In this case it's wool, making this mean <vocabulary>all wool</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
<kanji>Vertical</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji> is <vocabulary>vertical writing</vocabulary>. That's when you see Japanese and it's written top to bottom instead of sideways.
<kanji>Vertical</kanji> and <kanji>side</kanji> (horizontal). That means you have the <vocabulary>length and width</vocabulary> and the <vocabulary>vertical and horizontal</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Pure</kanji> plus 粋, which you might remember as "stylish" but which can mean <kanji>pure</kanji> as well. Wow, that's double the purity for this word. No wonder it also means <vocabulary>pure</vocabulary>! 

純粋 is usually for pure-hearted people or feelings, like 純粋な心 (a pure heart) or 純粋な気持ち (pure feelings). You can also say 純粋な疑問 — for <vocabulary>genuine</vocabulary> doubt or innocent wondering that just popped into your head, purely out of curiosity, with no hidden motives.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

粋 means <vocabulary>stylish</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>chic</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>tasteful</vocabulary>, but with a nuance of understated elegance or refined coolness. For example, arranging something behind the scenes so things go beautifully might be regarded as 粋 — a <vocabulary>classy</vocabulary> gesture done with style!
<kanji>God</kanji> is <kanji>holy</kanji>. Everything about a holy god is full of <vocabulary>holiness</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>holy</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji> is the <vocabulary>Bible</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>holy</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> is a <vocabulary>holy day</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Holy</kanji> <kanji>ground</kanji> is <vocabulary>holy land</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Magnet</kanji>ic <kanji>energy</kanji> is when <vocabulary>magnetism</vocabulary> occurs.
A <kanji>magnet</kanji> <kanji>stone</kanji> is a <vocabulary>magnet</vocabulary>. Magnets look like little stones, right?
A <kanji>magnet</kanji> <kanji>location</kanji> is an area with a <vocabulary>magnetic field</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>deep red</kanji> <kanji>tea</kanji> isn't a deep red tea... it's a <vocabulary>black tea</vocabulary>. If you think about it, a lot of black tea is really deep red, which is why a deep red tea is a black tea instead.

When you <kanji>shoot</kanji> something into someone that you actually have to <kanji>pour</kanji> (aka a liquid), you're shooting them up with a needle, giving them a <vocabulary>shot</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>injection</vocabulary>.
You <kanji>shoot</kanji> yourself at a mirror, and it is the <kanji>anti</kanji>-you. It is your <vocabulary>reflection</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Departure</kanji> and <kanji>shoot</kanji> something off. If you do that to something, you are going <vocabulary>to launch</vocabulary> it.
It <kanji>release</kanji>s and <kanji>shoot</kanji>s out of the bomb. It's not fire. It's <vocabulary>radiation</vocabulary>, and it sticks around a long time once it has been released.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>curtain</kanji> of <kanji>letter</kanji>s that goes on your screen are <vocabulary>subtitles</vocabulary>. Sometimes they have black bar backgrounds too, which are like curtains!

Just imagine a <kanji>black</kanji> <kanji>curtain</kanji> off in the background. You don't know what's behind it, but you know what's in front of it. Thing is, the thing in front of the curtain is controlled by whoever is behind the black curtain. This person is the <vocabulary>wirepuller</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mastermind</vocabulary> of the situation. Like the Wizard of Oz, or something.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>worship</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to worship</vocabulary>.

拝む generally means <vocabulary>to pray to</vocabulary> a deity, spirit, or revered object while assuming a worshipping position, such as bowing or clasping one's hands together in prayer. Additionally, 拝む can also mean <vocabulary>to see</vocabulary> with a sense of respect and reverence.

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: To Have A Look At Something

meaning_mnemonic:
You <kanji>worship</kanji> only the things you <kanji>see</kanji>. So, in order to see if something is worth worshiping, you'll go <vocabulary>to have a look at</vocabulary> that thing.

And just so you know, this is a very formal word used when you're trying to be polite. So keep that in mind, please!

You’re doing a bit of <kanji>infer</kanji>ring while you <kanji>determine</kanji> something, which means you’re not 100% sure, making this an <vocabulary>estimation</vocabulary>.

推定 refers to an estimation that’s generally based on some evidence or reasoning. You’ll often find this used in statistical or scientific contexts, where it refers to an educated guess or estimation based on available data.
To <kanji>infer</kanji> <kanji>reason</kanji> is to have <vocabulary>reasoning</vocabulary>.
To <kanji>infer</kanji> and <kanji>recommend</kanji> something is to give a <vocabulary>recommendation</vocabulary>. What do you recommend?
As for my<kanji>self</kanji>? I <kanji>recommend</kanji> this product. It is a <vocabulary>self-recommendation</vocabulary>. You make it of yourself!

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>recommend</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to recommend</vocabulary>. This word is often used in a positive context for recommending things, actions, and people by implying or pointing out their charms, merits, or both.

Although 薦める and 勧める are similar, there are subtle differences between the two. 勧める is often used to suggest that someone perform a specific action, often as friendly advice or encouragement. It can also be used when offering something, such as a drink. On the other hand, 薦める is used to recommend a person or thing as suitable for a particular situation, with a focus on endorsing the subject rather than a specific action.

You cause the <kanji>departure</kanji> of something in you (to the outside), then <kanji>brandish</kanji> it for all to see. You're sending it out to show everyone. That's why this means <vocabulary>to exhibit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to demonstrate</vocabulary>.

発揮する means <vocabulary>to bring out</vocabulary> one's abilities, strengths, or qualities in a visible or effective way. It's often used when someone performs well under pressure or maximizes their potential in a given situation.
Take your <kanji>finger</kanji> and <kanji>brandish</kanji> it to <vocabulary>command</vocabulary> the troops.
The <kanji>run alongside</kanji> <kanji>coast</kanji> basically just describes the <vocabulary>coast</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>run alongside</kanji> <kanji>sea</kanji> refers to the area along the coast. It can be either the sea that runs alongside the land or the land that runs alongside the sea, making it the <vocabulary>coastal waters</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>coastline</vocabulary>.

To <kanji>run alongside</kanji> the <kanji>line</kanji> (referring to the train line) means <vocabulary>along the train line</vocabulary>. What's along the train line? All kinds of things if you look carefully.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>run alongside</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to run alongside</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>origin</kanji> is the <vocabulary>origin</vocabulary>, but it also refers to the <vocabulary>ground spring</vocabulary>s, where the origin of water comes from.

The <kanji>origin</kanji> <kanji>family name</kanji> is the original dude. The original dude comes from the original and first novel ever written, the Tale of <kanji>Genji</kanji>. These kanji represent <vocabulary>Genji</vocabulary>, good ol' Genji. Perhaps hopping over to the reading will help you to know the meaning of this kanji.
The <kanji>electricity</kanji> <kanji>origin</kanji> is where the electricity comes from. It is the <vocabulary>power source</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>earthquake</kanji> <kanji>origin</kanji> <kanji>ground</kanji> is where the earthquake started from. It is the <vocabulary>epicenter</vocabulary>.

The kanji is <kanji>work</kanji> which means this verb has something to do with working. It's not straight up "to work," instead it's "<vocabulary>to work for</vocabulary>" or "<vocabulary>to be employed at</vocabulary>."

The things you <kanji>pass through</kanji> on your way to <kanji>work</kanji> are the things you see and run into during your <vocabulary>commute</vocabulary>.

Note that you can only use this word for commuting to work. You don’t use it to go to school unless you work at a school or something!
<kanji>Normal</kanji> <kanji>work</kanji> is work you do all day long, 8-hours a day, 5 days a week. That is <vocabulary>full time employment</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>full time</vocabulary>.

Giving <kanji>consent</kanji> to someone is similar to humbly listening to and accepting their words. So this word means <vocabulary>to humbly hear</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to accept</vocabulary>.

承る is a humble version of 聞く. Its past form 承りました is commonly used in professional settings to respectfully acknowledge and accept requests, information, or tasks.

You <kanji>consent</kanji> and <kanji>know</kanji> everything that's going on. You <vocabulary>consent</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>know</vocabulary> about all this. You're <vocabulary>aware</vocabulary> of it.
I <kanji>recognize</kanji> your <kanji>consent</kanji>. It is an <vocabulary>approval</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>recognition</vocabulary> of what I'm doing.

You'll find <kanji>delight</kanji> and <kanji>comfort</kanji> in these <kanji>streets</kanji>, because you have entered an <vocabulary>entertainment district</vocabulary>! 

歓楽街 refers to an area in a city where many nightlife entertainment venues, like bars, dance clubs, host or hostess clubs, and sometimes businesses offering sketchy red-light adult services, are clustered together.
To do <kanji>loss</kanji> to something means you are doing something to make something have loss. This is <vocabulary>to harm</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to injure</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>loss</kanji> will give you a <vocabulary>disadvantage</vocabulary>. So, try not to get any losses... or you'll be at a disadvantage.

Your <kanji>loss</kanji> comes from <kanji>damage</kanji> done to you. This is <vocabulary>damage</vocabulary>.

This word is usually used as a noun. It can occasionally be turned into verb by adding する, but this is very rare!
A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>loss</kanji> is a <vocabulary>heavy loss</vocabulary>.
An <kanji>all</kanji> <kanji>loss</kanji> is when you lose it all. It is a <vocabulary>total loss</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

<kanji>Small</kanji> <kanji>bean</kanji>s refer to a type of bean known as <vocabulary>azuki bean</vocabulary>s. It will help if you've heard of this delicious popular bean, because there's not really anything effective we can do with the meaning mnemonic from this point on. Just know that small beans are azuki beans.

A <kanji>supply</kanji> of <kanji>bean</kanji>s is when you take a bunch of beans, mash them up into a supply, and then ferment them all together to make them into <vocabulary>natto</vocabulary> (also known as <vocabulary>fermented soybeans</vocabulary>).
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>rot</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to rot</vocabulary>.
When something <kanji>rot</kanji>s and <kanji>eat</kanji>s away at something, that is <vocabulary>corrosion</vocabulary>. Not a good thing.

<kanji>Rot</kanji> and <kanji>failure</kanji> lead to <vocabulary>decomposition</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>rotting</vocabulary>. This word also has the related meaning of  <vocabulary>corruption</vocabulary>, similar to how "rotten" can mean "corrupt" in English.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, though it adds a few more meanings as well, like <vocabulary>nail</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>talon</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>hoof</vocabulary> or really any hard thing on the ends of fingers or feet.
When you <kanji>cut</kanji> your <kanji>claw</kanji> you use a <vocabulary>nail clipper</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>carve</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to carve</vocabulary>.

If you take the <kanji>time</kanji> and <kanji>carve</kanji> it onto a <kanji>surface</kanji>, then you've made a <vocabulary>timetable</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>schedule</vocabulary>.

時刻表 generally refers to a timetable or schedule for transportation, such as trains, buses, or flights.

A <kanji>deep</kanji> <kanji>carve</kanji> is very <vocabulary>serious</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>grave</vocabulary>. Just imagine getting cut with a sword. If the carve is deep, well, that's serious.

An <kanji>eyeball</kanji> <kanji>mirror</kanji> is something that refracts and focuses light into your eyeball in a different way so you can see better. Really, these things are glasses, not eye mirrors, but same sort of things when you get down to it. Just imagine someone wearing mirrors on their eyes, and when you ask them what those are for, they just say they're <vocabulary>glasses</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>government</kanji> behind a <kanji>curtain</kanji> is the <vocabulary>bakufu</vocabulary>. They didn't let anyone know their government secrets so they would hide behind that curtain and keep everything to themselves.

Something that's <kanji>valuable</kanji> and <kanji>heavy</kanji> is extremely <vocabulary>precious</vocabulary> and probably even more <vocabulary>valuable</vocabulary> than your less heavy things.

貴重 is used especially when something is rare, important, or hard to replace. You can use it for physical things, but you'll see it used to show appreciation for intangible things too, like 貴重なご意見 (your valuable opinion) or 貴重な体験 (a precious experience).

This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>welcome</kanji>, so it means a <vocabulary>welcome</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>greeting</vocabulary>, but it's usually used for someone who's coming and <vocabulary>meeting</vocabulary> you!

The kanji means <kanji>wound</kanji>, and this verb is intransitive, so it means <vocabulary>to be damaged</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to go bad</vocabulary>. After all, fruit with a wound on it is going bad, isn't it?

Everything that happened <kanji>since</kanji> you <kanji>descend</kanji>ed some stairs, is <vocabulary>hereafter</vocabulary>. It's all <vocabulary>after</vocabulary> the stairs thing you did, <vocabulary>since</vocabulary> you did it already.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>thin</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to get thin</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>thin</kanji> <kanji>body</kanji> type is called <vocabulary>lean</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>slim</vocabulary>. These days this is usually used in the context of <vocabulary>slimming</vocabulary> salons and massages you can get that may or may not work.

The kanji means <kanji>crotch</kanji> and the vocabulary also means <vocabulary>crotch</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>groin</vocabulary>.

Note that 股 is a little less specific than 股間, and can also be used for a <vocabulary>fork</vocabulary> in a road or path, which makes sense when you think about it, doesn't it?
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

You've got some <kanji>deep red</kanji> <kanji>leaves</kanji>. You'll usually see those during autumn, which makes this <vocabulary>autumn leaves</vocabulary>. Just <vocabulary>red leaves</vocabulary> is fine too, though.

Note that this refers not only to the leaves themselves, but also the process of them changing color, so this can also mean <vocabulary>leaves turning red</vocabulary>.

You’re doing a 飛ぶ and 込む at the same time, or you <kanji>jump</kanji> <kanji>into</kanji>, meaning you're <vocabulary>diving in</vocabulary>. Picture yourself standing somewhere up high, and then jumping to dive into a deep body of water.

Alternatively, this can also refer to doing something, or joining or going somewhere without an appointment, announcement, or prior registration, which is where the <vocabulary>dropping by</vocabulary> meaning comes in. For some use cases of this, check out our common word combinations and context sentences below!

You have the kanji for <kanji>hand</kanji> and the noun version of the verb for <kanji>wipe</kanji>. With a bit of imagination, that makes this a <vocabulary>hand towel</vocabulary>, or just a <vocabulary>towel</vocabulary>. They're a very specific kind of cloth towel, which is why you'll also often encounter them with their Japanese name <vocabulary>tenugui</vocabulary>.

Unlike お手拭き, which you learned about a few levels ago, 手拭い are always towels — never tissues. These thin, flat cloths are long and narrow, serving a variety of purposes beyond simply cleaning your hands. Their history is fascinating, so be sure to look them up!
